1. Introduction

In the 1950s, China's methanol industry emerged, undergoing accelerated technological upgrading and transformation to become a major producer. Methanol, known as "clean coal," "cheap oil," "mobile electricity," and "liquid hydrogen," finds extensive application across industries, from chemicals to energy[1]. G.A. Olah's[2] proposition of the "Methanol economy" anticipates its heightened prominence in the coming years, potentially ushering in a new fuel era. Currently, global methanol demand has doubled in the past decade, reaching 107 million tons[3]. With a 99.47 million-ton production capacity in 2022—an  $8.84\%$  increase from the previous year—China leads the world methanol industry in terms of new production capacity. In the same year, China's methanol production reached 8.306 million tons, marking a  $6.27\%$  year-on-year rise[4]. Methanol demand is still rising, propelled by consistent

domestic economic growth and quicker developments in the chemical, electronics, and automotive industries.[5]. Data indicates a notable surge in methanol consumption in China, reaching 7.808 million tons in apparent consumption in 2021, a  $5.96\%$  increase from the previous year [6]. This trend intensified in 2022, with apparent methanol consumption hitting 90 million tons, reflecting a  $15.26\%$  year-on-year rise[7]. Methanol, a vital chemical raw material, primarily serves downstream industries like olefins and acetic acid[3]. In 2021, methanol to olefins accounted for  $50.59\%$  of demand, followed by methanol fuel at  $15.66\%$  [8]. Diverse technologies presently produce methanol from fossil fuels such as natural gas, coal, crude oil, and biomass[9]. In China, the resource distribution - "more coal, less oil, and less gas"[4,10] has historically favored the coal-to-olefins route (58% in 2017), with coal-to-gas (17%) and natural gas-to-methanol (14%) following suit[11]. Methanol production, characterized by high energy intensity, often

leads to environmental challenges[12]. For instance, significant emissions of acidic gases (NOx, SOx,  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ ) and wastewater are commonplace [13] Additionally, gas leakage from various connecting valves during production is prevalent[14]. China's growing environmental focus accentuates the significance of studying the environmental sustainability of the methanol production industry [15].

Most environmental assessments of methanol production focus on individual technologies or a few specific routes[16]. However, there are very few thorough research on the most modern carbon dioxide hydrogenation to methanol technologies as well as older traditional energy-to-methanol methods. Notably, the Carbon Capture and Utilization (CCU) route's economic and environmental features have attracted a lot of interest[17]. González-Garay et al.[18] conducted an exhaustive evaluation of methanol production from carbon dioxide and renewable hydrogen process simulation and lifecycle analysis reveal that green methanol's current cost is 1.3 to 2.6 times higher than conventional fossil-based alternatives, mainly due to hydrogen pricing. Similarly, Pérez-Fortes et al.[19] assessed methanol production using hydrogen and captured carbon dioxide, indicating limited carbon emission reduction potential compared to traditional European methods. Cuellar-Franca et al.[20] reviewed 27 life cycle assessment (LCA) studies on carbon capture and storage (CCS) and carbon capture and utilization (CCU) technologies, highlighting CCU's heavy reliance on renewable energy and its associated environmental imbalances. They recommend that entire lifecycle analysis, electrolysis of renewable electricity for hydrogen synthesis, and carbon dioxide purification procedures be included in LCA study for pertinent insights. Thonemann[21] conducted an analysis of LCA-based  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  chemical production, finding no  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ -based technology superior in all impact categories to conventional methods. Methanol production pathways, including biomass gasification and  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  recovery from fossil fuel-fired power station flue gases, have been explored by Shamsul et al.[22], addressing bio-methanol's potential as a renewable resource, considering global demand, economic assessment, power density, and potential applications[23]. Zhen et al.[24] describe various methanol production approaches, encompassing coal, natural gas, coke-oven gas, hydrogen, and biomass. Dalena et al.[25] review prevalent feedstocks (natural gas,  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ , coke/biomass) and methanol production processes, including membrane reactor technology's catalytic conversion of methanol to high-grade hydrogen. Additionally, Blumberg et. Al[26] address methanol synthesis economics with different reforming technologies, evaluating process efficiency for steam reforming, autothermal reforming, and dry methane reforming, along with economic and sensitivity analyses. Gautam et al. present a comprehensive overview of thermo-chemical and biochemical routes for sustainable bio-methanol production from waste biomass. Chen Z et al.[11] conducted a "cradle to gate" life-cycle assessment of COTM (Coal Coking to Methanol), CGTM(Coal Gasification to Methanol), and NGTM(Natural Gas to Methanol), offering a comparison of three traditional technology roadmaps. However, research comparing the LCA of all methanol production routes in China remains a gap in the current body of work.

The previous study explores the effects of several methanol routes on the environment and economy. Nevertheless, a complete analysis of the sustainability's life cycle impact along these routes has not yet been carried out. Quantifying the ecological, human, and environmental impacts of CCU chemicals—especially green methanol—is essential to fully appreciating the possible repercussions of using such methods. This will help in the development of effective plans to mitigate these possible harms.
2. Methods

Per ISO guidelines (ISO, 2006a, b)[27], the LCA study involves four main steps: (1) defining goals and scope, (2) conducting a life cycle inventory (LCI) analysis, (3) performing a life cycle impact assessment (LCIA), and (4) interpretation. The study's foundational element lies in

clarifying objectives and scope, depicted in Fig. 1, from which the other three stages evolve. Initial stages encompass establishing the study's subject, gathering and scrutinizing data to pinpoint raw material sources, consumption patterns, and emissions. The establishment of assessment indicators comes next, and the results are then interpreted. Notably, one of the most popular tools in this industry is the eFootprint software.
2.1. Goal and scope definition

The environmental effects of five popular methanol production routes—CGTM, COTM, NGTM, BOTM, and CCTM—are compared in this study. These processes include direct carbon dioxide capture, hydrogenation with renewable energy sources, and the synthesis of methanol from coal, natural gas, biomass, and other conventional and innovative ways. In Fig. 2, the individual production paths are shown. The analysis uses a "cradle to gate" boundary and concentrates on the extraction of raw materials through the manufacturing of methanol, leaving out effects connected to facilities and infrastructure. Solid garbage is delivered to a nearby landfill while wastewater is processed and repurposed. In the fuel gas system, exhaust gases are either flared or recycled. Waste catalyst is not taken into account when calculating solid waste because the catalyst used in the process has a 3-5 year replacement cycle and stays constant during the production of methanol. Notably, because the post-production processes are the same for all routes, methanol application is not addressed. Figs. 3 to 7 show the system boundaries for each of the five methanol production routes (CGTM, COTM, NGTM, BOTM, and CCTM).
Case 1. Scope of Coal Gasification to MeOH (CGTM).

Fig. 3 illustrates the four stages of the coal gasification methanol (CGTM) production process[28] syngas generation, syngas purification, methanol synthesis, and methanol distillation. Initially, raw coal is mined, cleaned, and introduced into a gasifier utilizing Texaco's coal water slurry gasification technology. This operation necessitates additional air separation devices to provide pure oxygen. The water-shift gas reaction alters the  $\mathrm{H} / \mathrm{C}$  ratio of the crude syngas  $(2.1\sim 2.2)$ , resulting in a crude syngas containing hydrogen, carbon dioxide, and other components. Subsequently, the raw gas mixture undergoes purification through the Rectisol process, Eliminate  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ ,  $\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{S}$ ,  $\mathrm{CO}$ , and other compounds, while sulfur is recovered via the Super-clause procedure. Furthermore, some unreached gas is recycled back to the gasifier. Ultimately, under particular circumstances, a catalytic reaction  $(\mathrm{Cu} / \mathrm{ZnO} / \mathrm{Al}_2\mathrm{O}_3)$  converts clean gas and hydrogen into crude methanol. The next stage is to refine the crude methanol by distilling it in a special unit. This produces purified methanol.
Case 2. Scope of Coal Coking to MeOH (COTM).

Fig. 4 illustrates the similarities between the coal mining and handling stages of COTM and CGTM processes. The COTM process comprises three key stages: coal processing, coke production, and methanol production[29]. Once mined and washed, hard coal undergoes pyrolysis at approximately  $1100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$  in a coke oven, yielding coke and a substantial volume of crude coke oven gas. The resulting syngas includes CO,  $\mathrm{H}_2$ ,  $\mathrm{CH}_4$ , and other components, while pollutants such as benzene, ammonia, and sulfur are removed from the cooled coke oven gas. This syngas is introduced into a reforming reactor, where it undergoes reforming in the presence of an oxidant, resulting in a syngas featuring an  $\mathrm{H} / \mathrm{C}$  ratio of roughly 2.5. After that, the gas from the coke furnace is compressed to provide the perfect conditions for methanol synthesis. The syngas from the reformer is subjected to elevated pressure before being transferred to the methanol synthesis reactor. After the methanol is extracted from the unreacted syngas, the remaining crude syngas is fed back into the reformer. The last stage entails reprocessing the crude methanol in a distillation unit to produce refined methanol.
Case 3. Scope of Natural Gas to MeOH (NGTM).

As depicted in Fig. 5, the NGTM technology roadmap comprises two primary stages: natural gas extraction and processing, and the complete methanol production process (including syngas generation through steam reforming)[30]. After mining, a sizable amount of acidic gasses are present in the collected natural gas. Chemical absorption is first used to remove acidic gasses such as SO2 and H2S. After the acid gas is desulfurized, the natural gas is steam reformated to create syngas, and the  $\mathrm{H / C}$  ratio is adjusted to about 3.0. After that, the syngas is compressed and added to the synthesis reactor to create methanol. Recycled syngas is put back into the syngas furnace for additional reaction if it hasn't already. Many impurities and water are retained in the resulting crude methanol, which is then eliminated in the distillation unit to produce refined methanol.
Case 4. Scope of Biomass to MeOH (BOTM).

Fig. 6 illustrates the methanol synthesis process from biomass gasification, yielding biomass methanol[31]. An essential component of effectively converting high-grade biomass resources is the biomass conversion system. The supply of raw materials, biomass gasification, synthesis gas pretreatment, methanol synthesis, and end product generation are the four main steps of the process. First, biomass is subjected to necessary pretreatment, which includes granulation and drying. Subsequently, biomass gasification produces feedstock gas consisting mainly of CO,  $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ ,  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ , and  $\mathrm{CH}_4$ . Condensation is then employed to extract the fuel gas from the reactor. This collected gas undergoes water gas reforming (WGS) to adjust the  $\mathrm{CO} / \mathrm{H}_{2}$  ratio, followed by the removal of acidic gases such as  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  and H2S through the acid gas stripping system (AGR). The purified syngas is compressed and added to the methanol synthesizer in the last step, where a catalyst helps to produce crude methanol. High-quality methanol products are produced by further refining this crude methanol using the crude unit. This thorough
procedure emphasizes how important each step is to producing biomass methanol in an efficient and effective manner.
Case 5. Scope of  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  Capture to MeOH (CCTM).

The CCTM process for methanol conversion involves three main steps: hydrogen production through water electrolysis,  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  capture, and methanol synthesis[32], illustrated in Fig. 7. Large-scale water electrolysis powered by clean energy produces  $\mathrm{O}_{2}$  and  $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ . The gas is processed according to the Hua-neng Beijing  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  capture demonstration unit's process flow, going through desulfurization, denitrification, and dust removal before entering the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  capture unit as wet saturated steam. After being cleaned, the flue gas is sent up the absorption tower, where it reacts at between 50 and  $60^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$  with the MEA packing. Subsequently, the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ -rich solution is extracted from the bottom of the absorber tower and fed into the vaporizer. The vaporizer tower contains a reboiler at its base, heating and vaporizing the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ . This allows it to mix with the rising gas, composed of  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ ,  $\mathrm{H}_{2}\mathrm{O}$ , and a small solvent

fraction. Controlled at  $105^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$ , the vapor tower facilitates the release of  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  from the mixture. Following this, the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  stream undergoes mist elimination, condensation, and reflux to eliminate water and solvent, resulting in the production of  $99.5\% \sim 99.7\%$  pure  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  gas.

The cathodic electrolyte in the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  electroreduction unit is supplied with high-purity  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ , which is injected into an ionic liquid and water solution until saturation.[33,34]. The electrolyzer's cathode chamber receives this mixture after which  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  is reduced to methanol. These processes take place under ambient pressure and temperature. While oxygen is produced on the anode side, hydrogen is produced on the cathode side. A proton exchange membrane separates the chambers to prevent unwanted reactions. An aqueous solution comprising unreacted  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ , ionic liquid, water, and methanol is produced during  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  electroreduction. Additional separation and purification of unreacted  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  and solvent are needed to produce a methanol product (with a methanol mass fraction  $>99\%$ ) that satisfies criteria. Inputs making up less than  $1\%$  of the total are not included in the data collecting procedure for unit

processes (with a total disregard not exceeding  $3\%$  of the total input). Carbon emissions from methanol transportation and usage stages are not considered. The evaluation system boundary for the cradle-to-gate study encompasses  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  feedstock acquisition,  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  conversion to methanol, and methanol purification processes.

2.3. Life cycle impact assessment methods

The study employs eFootprint software for specialized production models. The CML2001 and Eco-indicator 99[42] methodologies characterize, normalize, standardize, and weight the life cycle environmental load inventory data for each route, enabling the calculation of the corresponding environmental impact values. Please refer to Fig. 8 for the methodological framework.

The five methanol processes are commonly evaluated and compared at the mid-point (MP) and end-point (EP) levels. The MP level evaluation is problem-oriented and focuses on environmental issues, evaluating the environmental mechanisms that link pollutant emissions to harm, while ignores the effects of environmental degradation on resources, ecosystems, and humans. The EP level assessment is a damage-oriented technique that assesses the detrimental effects on ecosystems and human health.

The CML2001 technique was used to assess environmental impacts at the MP level, and ten typical impact categories were chosen as MP level indicators. The midpoint impact categories in this case are (1) global warming potential 100 years GWP; (2) abiotic depletion potential ADP; (3) eutrophication potential EP; (4) abiotic depletion potential (ADP); (5) human toxicity potential (HTP); (6) ozone depletion potential (ODP); (7) photochemical oxidation potential (PCOP); (8) freshwater aquatic ecotoxicity potential (FAETP); (9) marine aquatic ecotoxicity potential (MAETP); (10) terrestrial ecotoxicity potential (TETP). 3. Results and discussion

The five common methanol pathways share similar ingredient profiles, utilizing 13 distinct input materials from the environment, encompassing both non-renewable and renewable resources. Emissions are categorized into inventory, air, water, and soil emissions. These emissions comprise heavy metals, inorganic and organic chemicals, with topsoil, waste, and degraded goods as the primary stockpiles. Notably, heavy metals and inorganic compounds dominate pollutants released into the air, water, and agricultural and industrial soils.

As a leading producer and consumer, China's methanol industry is expected to grow alongside emerging downstream industries. However, environmental concerns arise due to its heavy reliance on fossil fuels for production. This study employs the eFootprint software to comprehensively assess the environmental impact of various methanol production pathways - coal to methanol (CGTM), coke oven gas to methanol (COTM), natural gas to methanol (NGTM), biomass to methanol (BOTM), and carbon dioxide hydrogenation to methanol (CCTM). Through a life cycle evaluation, this research examines the environmental footprint of these pathways.
3.1. Life cycle assessment results and environmental performance

Fig. 9 illustrates the material and energy flows for each of the five pathways. The data for the methanol production routes were organized based on input and output analyses within the life cycle software to gain clarity on pollutant emissions. Coal mining requires  $1.25\mathrm{kg}$  of diesel,  $12.5\mathrm{kWh}$  of electricity, and  $0.7\mathrm{t}$  of water to yield  $1\mathrm{t}$  of coal.

In Fig. 9(a), coal gasification employs  $1.23\mathrm{t}$  of syngas,  $1.533\mathrm{t}$  of hard coal,  $1.53\mathrm{kg}$  of crude oil,  $14.2\mathrm{kg}$  of water, and  $825\mathrm{kWh}$  of electricity to produce  $1\mathrm{t}$  of methanol. 3.3. Electric power optimization analysis

Electricity has the greatest potential to lessen environmental consequences because it is the technology route that is most environmentally sensitive. Therefore, in this study, four forms of clean power—namely, wind power, hydropower, nuclear power, and photovoltaic power—along with conventional coal power are selected along with hybrid power in the base case scenario in order to optimize power, based on the evolution and development of China's power mix. In order to make recommendations for cleaner production in the methanol industry, a new LCA analysis is carried out to estimate the environmental effect reduction potential of the electric power optimization.

Based on China's electricity structure and development trend, this study chose the blended electricity results of the base case scenario and the accounting results of solar, wind, hydropower, nuclear, and coal power in five methanol production lines. According to the Gabi database,  $74.23\%$  of blended electricity is produced by burning coal,  $16.9\%$  by hydropower,  $2.59\%$  by wind,  $2.05\%$  by heavy oil,  $1.66\%$  by natural gas,  $1.24\%$  by gas, and less than  $1\%$  by other fuels.

Fig. 25 illustrates the outcomes of an analysis of the electricity

optimization and reduction potential based on the change in the type of input electricity during the life cycle for the mitigation potential of the total environmental impacts of the five methanol production routes. Only  $2.4\%$ ,  $3.6\%$ ,  $2.4\%$ ,  $2.3\%$ , and  $3.2\%$  less environmental impact is experienced overall if hybrid power completely replaces coal power. The possibility for mitigation is clear if all of the electricity is generated from specified clean and renewable energy sources, such as nuclear power. For instance, using  $100\%$  wind power would lower the combined environmental consequences for the five routes by, respectively,  $79.6\%$ ,  $64.4\%$ ,  $81.4\%$ ,  $81.0\%$ , and  $54.9\%$ . Although hydropower has the greatest potential for environmental impact reduction of the four typical routes for the production of methanol, the combined environmental impact magnitude values are very close, all around 3.00E-09, allowing for results that are comparable to hydropower in terms of combined environmental impacts if  $100\%$  nuclear or wind power can be applied. Among the four typical routes for producing methanol, hydropower has the best potential for reduction in the scenarios when clean electricity is used. If  $100\%$  nuclear or wind power can be deployed in the typical pathways, the combined environmental effect magnitude values are extremely close to each other, all hovering around 3.00E-09, making it conceivable to achieve outcomes comparable to hydropower in terms of the combined environmental impacts. However, in the case where all electricity is generated by PV, the reduction potential of the CGTM, COTM, NGTM, and BOTM routes is, respectively,  $72.4\%$ ,  $59.6\%$ ,  $73.7\%$ , and  $72.6\%$ , which is slightly higher than the other cleaner energy based electricity but also much lower than the impact value of coal power.

Many gasses, like as CO2, SO2, and silicon tetrachloride, are used in the production of PV panels, which would negatively damage human health and the ecology, thereby having a bigger total environmental impact. This is the primary reason why PV power generation has a greater environmental load.

Fig. 25 further indicates that the CGTM approach holds significant potential for mitigating environmental impacts. When utilizing  $100\%$  of a clean energy source—such as wind, hydropower, or nuclear energy—the cumulative environmental impact values for both the CGTM and COGM pathways tend to converge. Additionally, in scenarios involving coal-fired electricity, the COGM, NGTM, and BOTM routes exhibit competitiveness with the CGTM pathway employing  $100\%$  clean energy power. These findings suggest that the CGTM route can vie with other conventional pathways by decommissioning power sources and circumventing existing high-pollution and energy-intensive processes. However, the outlook for the novel  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  hydrogenation route is less promising; even after electricity optimization, its overall environmental impacts surpass those of the COTM, NGTM, and BOTM routes. This underscores electricity as the paramount influencing factor within this new route, far surpassing the power dependency observed in conventional methanol production pathways. Returning to the sensitivity analysis, this research also ascertain that electricity not only possesses greater potential to influence the environmental impact of the CCTM route, but another critical parameter, steam, exhibits exceedingly high sensitivity as well.
Based on Fig. 26, the integrated environmental impact reduction

Specifically, when applying hydropower at a  $100\%$  utilization rate, the emission reduction potential reaches an impressive  $85.2\%$ . These findings underscore the growing significance of co-optimizing steam and electricity to facilitate cleaner production within emerging pathways. Concurrently, it's critical to recognize that the cleaner production from the new route is not up to par. The examination of process percentages indicates that, in the CCTM framework, the stage of hydrogen generation is mostly responsible for reducing environmental impact, particularly when it comes to the use of clean electricity. 3.3.3. Analysis and discussion of electric power optimization conclusion

The primary methanol production process in China is called CGTM; however, due to the significant environmental impact of both the synthesis gas and the methanol manufacturing process, CGTM has the worst environmental effects. Optimizing electric power is the only way to manufacture it with the least amount of environmental damage.

China is where most coke is made. One of the initial applications of COTM was the production of methanol from coke oven gas. Compared to the CGTM route, this one has less of an environmental impact because it does not require the coal gasification process. As a result, developing COTM is an important and workable way to reduce carbon emissions

and conserve energy while utilizing the benefits of the circular economy. Even though electric power optimization puts the COTM route closer to the CGTM route and higher than the NGTM route, there are still many opportunities to reduce the route's environmental impact. Thus, clean electricity is an essential part of COTM's clean manufacturing.

Despite the limitations associated with raw materials, NGTM remains the most ecologically friendly method of producing methanol. However, the possibility of importing cheap methane from abroad has driven China's upcoming NGTM plan, which is motivated by the success of shale gas extraction in the United States. Utilizing electric power optimization also has the potential to significantly reduce future environmental effects associated with the NGTM process.

Both the BOTM and NGTM pathways employ state-of-the-art cleaner production technologies. China produces 6.7 billion of the 170 billion tons of biomass produced annually worldwide, thanks to its large biomass energy reservoir. The process of hydroxyl molecule production from biomass provides unparalleled advantages for the economical utilization of carbon and oxygen resources. Optimizing electricity use is a key tactic that shares similarities with NGTM's capacity to lessen environmental impact.

Turning to CCTM, the country's industrialization has been impeded by economic and other factors. Based on current impact analysis, its environmental benefits are not competitively advantaged at this time. This is especially true when hydrogen is produced using wind energy;

the energy-intensive production process of the carbon source,  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  capture, places a significant environmental burden on the technology roadmap. Only by working together to optimize steam and electricity can significant environmental benefits be realized.
4. Conclusions

The typical technology routes for methanol production in China are CGTM, COTM, NGTM, BOTM and CCTM. This paper uses the LCA method to analyze each route's combined environmental impacts, process impacts, and sub-process impacts on the environment. It also examines each route's 10 types of environmental impacts and 2 types of endpoint impacts at the midpoint level. Electricity is discovered to be the most sensitive input parameter for environmental implications on the basis of sensitivity analysis. As a result, the electric power optimization using clean power replacement method was used to quantify the decrease potential of each type of environmental impact. The results show that,
1) The CGTM technology route exhibits the most significant combined environmental impact, surpassing that of the other four routes by 2.0 to 3.6 times.

2) CGTM has the greatest environmental impact of all of these approaches, which is mostly related to the syngas manufacturing phase. In contrast, COGM and NGTM are primarily responsible for the environmental impacts that arise during the methanol production phase. Significantly, the most significant environmental impact is attributed to the  $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$  collecting process within CCTM.

3) Across these five technological approaches, environmental degradation constitutes  $73\%$  to  $81\%$  of the impacts, with human health being impacted  $10\%$  to  $12\%$  of the time. Sensitivity analysis highlights electricity as the most responsive indicator to environmental implications. This holds true for power consumption during syngas production in the CGTM route and electricity usage in methanol synthesis stages within the COTM, NGTM, and BOTM routes. The sensitivity of steam consumption in the CCTM route is also notable.

4) Through electric power optimization, it is evident that employing  $100\%$  clean energy sources such as wind, hydro, nuclear, and solar power can lead to reductions of  $79.6\%$ ,  $64.4\%$ ,  $81.4\%$ , and  $81.0\%$  in cumulative impacts for CGTM, COTM, NGTM, and BOTM routes respectively. Conversely, the potential reduction achieved solely
through electricity optimization in the CCTM route is  $54.9\%$ , and when optimizing both steam and electricity, the combined environmental impact can be lowered by  $85.2\%$ .

5) Although the CGTM route is thought to be the least environmentally friendly, the COTM route's environmental impact is similar to that of the CGTM route because of the utilization of  $100\%$  clean power. As a result, the all-clean energy-powered CGTM route can compete with the coal-powered COTM and NGTM lines in terms of environmental impact.

6) NGTM emerges as the most environmentally conscientious approach to methanol production. As for CCTM, its environmental benefits align with those of NGTM when powered by hydropower, wind power, or nuclear energy. This underscores the importance of aligning CCTM development with renewable energy sources.

7) In conclusion, the methanol industry can achieve its objectives of clean and sustainable development through adjustments in technological structure and the prudent utilization of clean energy resources.
